Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Channel Energy Center (CEC) is located in Harris County, Texas within the property boundary of LyondellBascell. CEC is a gas-fired combustion turbine power plant that produces electricity. As a means of reducing nitrogen oxide emissions from the three combustion turbines, three heat recovery steam generators (HRSG) and three auxiliary boilers, anhydrous ammonia is in injected into the turbine exhaust streams. The anhydrous ammonia is stored on-site in two storage tanks, located on the northwest side of the facility. The storage capacity of each tank exceeds the threshold quantity for RMP applicability. There are not other toxic or flammable substances on site that exceed RMP thresholds. Passive mitigation exists in the form of a dike around the tank and active mitigation in the form of deluge, which limits the spread of ammonia.



Off-Site Consequence Analysis

As required by the RMP rule, the worst case scenario is the highly unlikely catastrophic rupture of one of the anhydrous ammonia storage tanks. The release duration is ten minutes. The 13,000 gallon tanks are each limited to 85% of the storage capacity by administrative controls, including operating procedures and high level alarms. The EPA's RMP*Comp was used in this analysis.  Based on the analysis, public and environmental receptors would be affected by the worst case scenario.



The alternative release scenario, although unlikely, is a more realistic scenario than the worst case scenario. It was analyzed as the failure of the pipe connection on a delivery tanker truck. The release would be mitigated via a water deluge system installed around the outside of the tank. The EPA's Risk Management Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration was used in the analysis. Based on the analysis, public receptors would not be affected by the alternative release scenario.



Accidental Release Prevention Program

CEC is subject to OSHA's PSM Standard and Program 3

of EPA's RMP rule. The accidental release prevention program at CEC includes:



Employee Participation

All CEC employees are actively encouraged to participate in the accidental release prevention program. Each employee is urged to participate in the continual upgrading and maintaining of all health and safety programs. Employee involvement is achieved through direct participation on a voluntary basis, active consultation with affected employees, and representative participation in the process hazard analysis. Employees have access to all information as required under the PSM and RMP regulations.



Process Safety Information

CEC maintains a variety of technical documents to ensure that the process hazards are understood and that the plant is operated and maintained in a safe manner. These documents include information concerning the hazardous of ammonia, process technology, and process equipment. This information is updated when changes in the process occur. Information concerning the hazards of ammonia includes toxicity information, permissible exposure limits, physical, reactivity, corrosivity, thermal and stability data, and the effects of inadvertent mixing. Information concerning the process technology includes process flow information, process chemistry, maximum intended inventory information, safe upper and lower process limits, and consequences of deviating from safe limits.  Information concerning the process equipment includes the materials of construction, piping specifications, piping and instrument diagrams, electrical area classification, relief design calculations and design basis, design codes and standards employed, material and energy balances and safety systems.



Process Hazard Analysis

CEC has a comprehensive program to ensure that the hazards associated with the processes are systematically identified and controlled. The analysis is conducted in accordance with regulatory requirements, general industry standards, and guidance from safety

organizations such as the Center for Chemical Process Safety. The plant has a system in place to ensure that the analysis recommendations are resolved in a timely manner.



Operating Procedures

CEC maintains written operating procedures that address the various modes of process operations, including initial startup, normal startups and shutdowns, emergency shutdowns, emergency operations, normal operations, and temporary operations (in accordance with new MOC). The procedures also discuss safe upper and lower process limits, consequences of deviation from the safe limits, and how to return the process to safe operations. The procedures are readily available to operations personnel and are reviewed and certified annually. 



Training

All operations personnel of CEC are initially trained in an overview of the ammonia process and the procedures to safety operate the process. All operations personnel of CEC are initially trained in an overview of the ammonia process and the procedures to safely operate the process. Operations personnel will receive refresher training at a minimum of every three years.



Contractors

CEC uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors will work on or near the ammonia process equipment, the plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors are aware of the hazards of the process, understand what to do in the event of an emergency, understand site safety rules, and inform plant personnel of any hazards they encounter during their work. CEC also evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection process.



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR)

CEC conducts a PSSR for any new facility or significant facility modification. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety systems, procedures, training, and equipment are prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional ch

eck to make sure construction is in accordance with design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accidental release prevention programs are properly maintained. 



Mechanical Integrity

CEC has implemented practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The program includes: (1) the development of a maintenance schedule for equipment in the ammonia process and critical safety equipment, (2) developing written maintenance procedures, (3) conducting maintenance training, (4) performing and documenting inspections, (5) correcting identified equipment deficiencies, and (6) applying quality assurance measures to ensure replacement equipment meets the requirement specifications.



Hot Work Permits

CEC has a hot work permit program in place to ensure worker and process safety. The hot work permit program is designed to control spark-producing activities and to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before work begins in the process area. These procedures (and others), along with the training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that maintenance activities are performed safely.



Management of Change

CEC has a system in place to ensure safety concerns associated with changes to the ammonia process are reviewed and addressed prior to the change. The changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards as well as to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. The system requires that process safety information and operating procedures are updated and that operations and maintenance personnel are trained before the change is implemented.



Incident Investigation

CEC will promptly inves

tigate all incidents that resulted in, or could reasonably be expected to result in, the catastrophic release of ammonia. The findings of the investigation, along with any corrective actions taken to prevent recurrence of the incident, will be reviewed with all affected personnel (including contractors).



Compliance Audits

To ensure that the accidental release prevention program is functioning properly, CEC will conduct a compliance audit every three years. The plant will quickly resolve any deficiencies noted by the audit team, and will review the report and corrective actions taken with all affected personnel.



Additional Safety Systems

CEC has additional safety systems in place to prevent accidental releases of ammonia, as well as systems to lessen the impact of accidental releases. These systems include:

*Redundant instrumentation to monitor critical process parameters

*Redundant critical equipment

*Automated shutdown systems

*Pressure relief valves

*Water deluge system to wash ammonia vapors out of the air



Five-Year Accident History

CEC began operations in 2001. Since that time, there has been one RMP reportable accident at the plant occuring on July 23, 2007. There has not been any qualifying accidents in the last five years. 



Emergency Response Program

CEC maintains a written emergency response program. The program addresses all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, spill response measures, evacuation plans and personnel accounting, notification of emergency response agencies and the public in the event of a release. The emergency response program is coordinated with the Southeast Regional LEPC and with the LyondellBasell.
